news_summary: A comet from beyond our solar system has been found to carry a key molecule essential for life, offering exciting insights into the building blocks of life in space.
news_summary_fr: Une comète située au-delà de notre système solaire s'est révélée porteuse d'une molécule essentielle à la vie, ce qui ouvre des perspectives intéressantes sur les éléments constitutifs de la vie dans l'espace.
news_summary_es: Se ha descubierto que un cometa de más allá de nuestro sistema solar transporta una molécula esencial para la vida, lo que ofrece interesantes perspectivas sobre los componentes básicos de la vida en el espacio.

articles.title: Comet 3I/ATLAS from beyond solar system carries key molecule for life
articles.summary: Astronomers have discovered that 3I/ATLAS is carrying methanol and other chemicals that were probably important in the origin of life
articles.content:
Astronomers have discovered that 3I/ATLAS is carrying methanol and other chemicals that were probably important in the origin of life

Comet 3I/ATLAS is only the third known visitor to our solar system from elsewhere International Gemini Observatory/NOIRLab/NSF/AURA/Shadow the Scientist; J. Miller & M. Rodriguez (Intl Gemini Observatory/NSF NOIRLab), T.A. Rector (University of Alaska Anchorage/NSF NOIRLab), M. Zamani (NSF NOIRLab)

The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS is belching out carbon-rich chemical compounds at higher rates than almost any other comet in our solar system. One of these compounds is methanol, a key ingredient in prebiotic chemistry that hasn’t been seen in other interstellar objects.

3I/ATLAS, which is only the third visitor to our solar system from elsewhere in the galaxy, appears to be quite unlike any comet from our own galactic neighbourhood. As it travelled towards the sun, an envelope of water vapour and gas rapidly grew around it, which also contained much greater amounts of carbon dioxide than we see in typical solar system comets. The comet’s light also appeared to be much redder than is typical, indicating a possible unusual surface chemistry, and it began releasing its gases while relatively far away from the sun, an indication that it might not have passed close to another star for hundreds of millions of years, or since it left its home star system.

Now, Martin Cordiner at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland and his colleagues have used the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile to discover that 3I/ATLAS is producing significant amounts of hydrogen cyanide gas, and even larger amounts of gaseous methanol. “Molecules like hydrogen cyanide and methanol are at trace abundances and not the dominant constituents of our own comets,” says Cordiner. “Here we see that, actually, in this alien comet they’re very abundant.”

Cordiner and his team found the hydrogen cyanide gas was coming from relatively close to the rocky core of the comet, and was being produced in quantities of around a quarter to a half a kilogram per second. Methanol was also found in the core, but it also appeared to be produced in significant quantities in the comet’s coma, which is the long tail of dust and gas that is many kilometres away from the comet itself.

Methanol appeared in much greater quantities than the hydrogen cyanide – around 40 kilograms per second – and makes up around 8 per cent of the total vapour coming from the comet, compared with around 2 per cent for standard solar system comets. The differences in location for these two molecules also suggests that the comet’s nucleus is not uniform, which could eventually tell us about how it formed, says Cordiner.

While methanol is a relatively simple carbon-containing compound, it is a key stepping stone to producing more complex molecules essential for life, says Cordiner, and would likely be produced in high quantities when other chemical reactions that produce these molecules are occurring. “It seems really chemically implausible that you could go on a path to very high chemical complexity without producing methanol,” says Cordiner.

Josep Trigo-Rodríguez at the Institute of Space Sciences in Spain and his colleagues have predicted that a comet high in metals like iron should also produce relatively large amounts of methanol, because liquid water, freed up by the sun’s heat, would begin pushing through the comet’s nucleus and chemically reacting with its iron compounds – a process that should create methanol. As such, finding evidence of methanol in the comet’s coma could be a sign that the comet is relatively metal rich, he says.

This finding has meaningful impact for the general public by advancing knowledge of astrobiology and the potential for life-building molecules in the galaxy. The article provides substantial context and details about the comet's unique chemistry and the importance of methanol in prebiotic chemistry.
articles.personality_title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS carries important molecule linked to life’s origins
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Comet 3I/ATLAS is only the third known comet from outside our solar system to visit us. Unlike comets formed near the sun, it comes from another star system far away in our galaxy.

**What happened** – Scientists used a powerful telescope in Chile called ALMA to study 3I/ATLAS as it traveled through our solar system. They found that the comet releases large amounts of methanol, a chemical important for building life, along with hydrogen cyanide gas. These chemicals were found in much higher amounts than in comets from our own solar system.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because methanol is a key step in forming complex molecules needed for life. Finding it in an interstellar comet shows that such life-related chemicals exist beyond our solar system. It also suggests that 3I/ATLAS has a unique makeup, possibly rich in metals, which could help scientists learn how comets form in other star systems.

**What’s next step** – Researchers will continue studying 3I/ATLAS and other interstellar objects to better understand their chemistry and origins. This could reveal more about how life-building molecules spread across the galaxy and how different star systems create comets.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The discovery of methanol and other chemicals in comet 3I/ATLAS offers new clues about the building blocks of life coming from beyond our solar system.
articles.personality_title_fr: La comète interstellaire 3I/ATLAS transporte une molécule clé liée aux origines de la vie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La comète 3I/ATLAS est seulement la troisième comète connue en provenance d’un autre système stellaire à visiter notre système solaire. Contrairement aux comètes formées près du Soleil, elle vient d’un autre système stellaire lointain dans notre galaxie.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques ont utilisé un puissant télescope au Chili, appelé ALMA, pour étudier 3I/ATLAS pendant son passage dans notre système solaire. Ils ont découvert que la comète libère de grandes quantités de méthanol, une molécule importante pour la formation de la vie, ainsi que du cyanure d’hydrogène. Ces substances sont présentes en quantités bien plus élevées que dans les comètes de notre propre système solaire.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car le méthanol est une étape clé pour former des molécules complexes nécessaires à la vie. Le trouver dans une comète interstellaire montre que ces molécules liées à la vie existent au-delà de notre système solaire. Cela suggère aussi que 3I/ATLAS a une composition unique, peut-être riche en métaux, ce qui peut aider les scientifiques à comprendre comment les comètes se forment dans d’autres systèmes stellaires.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront à étudier 3I/ATLAS et d’autres objets interstellaires pour mieux comprendre leur chimie et leur origine. Cela pourrait révéler comment les molécules à l’origine de la vie se répandent dans la galaxie et comment différents systèmes stellaires créent des comètes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La découverte de méthanol et d’autres molécules dans la comète 3I/ATLAS apporte de nouveaux indices sur les briques de la vie venant de l’extérieur de notre système solaire.
articles.personality_title_es: El cometa interestelar 3I/ATLAS lleva una molécula clave vinculada a los orígenes de la vida
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El cometa 3I/ATLAS es solo el tercer cometa conocido que viene de fuera de nuestro sistema solar. A diferencia de los cometas formados cerca del sol, proviene de otro sistema estelar lejano en nuestra galaxia.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos usaron un telescopio muy potente en Chile llamado ALMA para estudiar 3I/ATLAS mientras viajaba por nuestro sistema solar. Encontraron que el cometa libera grandes cantidades de metanol, una sustancia química importante para formar la vida, junto con gas de cianuro de hidrógeno. Estos químicos están en mucho mayor cantidad que en cometas de nuestro propio sistema solar.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque el metanol es un paso clave para formar moléculas complejas necesarias para la vida. Encontrarlo en un cometa interestelar muestra que estas sustancias relacionadas con la vida existen más allá de nuestro sistema solar. También sugiere que 3I/ATLAS tiene una composición única, posiblemente rica en metales, lo que puede ayudar a los científicos a entender cómo se forman los cometas en otros sistemas estelares.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán estudiando 3I/ATLAS y otros objetos interestelares para entender mejor su química y origen. Esto podría revelar cómo se esparcen las moléculas que forman la vida por la galaxia y cómo diferentes sistemas estelares crean cometas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El descubrimiento de metanol y otros químicos en el cometa 3I/ATLAS ofrece nuevas pistas sobre los ingredientes de la vida que vienen de fuera de nuestro sistema solar.
